thread.title: Cyclones Gameday: Keys to victory at Texas Tech
thread.title_full: Cyclones Gameday: Keys to victory at Texas Tech

title: Cyclones Gameday: Keys to victory at Texas Tech
text:
Cyclones Gameday: Keys to victory at Texas Tech Some people say this is one of the few remaining games Iowa State can win. Post to Facebook Cyclones Gameday: Keys to victory at Texas Tech Some people say this is one of the few remaining games Iowa State can win. Check out this story on desmoinesregister.com: http://dmreg.co/1Lk8yKD Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 1 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Cyclones Gameday: Keys to victory at Texas Tech Randy Peterson and Tommy Birch discuss this week's Texas Tech game. Randy Peterson , rpeterson@dmreg.com 2:39 p.m. CDT October 8, 2015 Iowa State's Mike Warren will look to have another big game when the Cyclones travel to Lubbock. (Photo: Brian Powers/The Register) 53 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
LUBBOCK, Texas — Some people say this is one of the few remaining games Iowa State can win, mentioning Red Raiders in the same breath as Longhorns and possibly Wildcats. 
That’s why winning Saturday’s 2:30 p.m. game in Lubbock is so important for a program that seeks consecutive Big 12 Conference wins for the first time since beating Kansas and West Virginia at the end of 2013. 
It’s not a great Texas Tech team (3-2) that the Cyclones face. It’s actually their scheduling appetizer before facing TCU and Baylor on successive Saturdays. 
Story lines? Here’s a few: 
Iowa State must be patient 
Texas Tech will score; the Red Raiders own the best passing offense in the country, at 423.8 yards a game. They’ll probably even score on their first possession – they usually do. 
But Iowa State needn’t get flustered, because Texas Tech is prone to making mistakes. 
You think Iowa State’s 14 penalties against Toledo were a lot? They were, but get this: 
The Red Raiders committed 17 in last Saturday’s 63-35 loss at Baylor. The offensive line was flagged for seven penalties: four for illegal procedure, two for holding and one for illegal receiver downfield. 
No missed tackles 
Against Kansas, Iowa State could afford to miss a tackle or two. Against Texas Tech? Not so much. 
The Red Raiders thrive on having sprinter receivers turn medium-range passes into long gains with their shiftiness and their where-are-they-now elusiveness. 
The same is true against quarterback Patrick Mahomes, who can turn a bad play or two into something big. 
In the past, this has been the Cyclones’ bugaboo; tackling hasn’t always been the defense's strong suit. But with guys like Jay Jones and Demond Tucker and more experienced players in the secondary, that aspect of the game might be better on this occasion. The burgeoning freshman running back opens up a lot of opportunities for Iowa State's offense Randy Peterson 
Keep drives alive 
The best way to keep the second-best Big 12 quarterback (behind TCU’s Trevone Boykin) from striking early and often is to keep him on the sidelines. You can’t throw touchdown passes when you’re can’t throw. 
Turning this offense that averages 602.8 yards a game into spectators as long as possible — that’s the best way to beat these guys. 
Cyclone tight ends caught three passes against Kansas — the first receptions for that position group this season. Ben Boesen and Justin Chandler must catch more, because it’s not like they need to be held back to block — Texas Tech has sacked quarterbacks just three times in five games. 
Involving the tight ends will help free standout tailback Mike Warren, as well as create opportunities for receivers. Freshman running back Mike Warren talks about moving forward after two breakout games. Tommy Birch 
And speaking of Warren 
This could be an even bigger day for the redshirt freshman, who rushed for 175 yards last Saturday against Kansas. He’ll be facing a defense against whom opponents have averaged 277.4 rushing yards a game — the worst rush defense in the Big 12. 
“I know I can do better,” Warren said after his breakout game against the Jayhawks. 
For the Cyclones to win, that confidence must show up Saturday, not only with Warren, but also the offensive line that plows his path. 
Big game for quarterback Sam? 
It could happen, considering Texas Tech not only has the worst rush defense in the Big 12, but also has sacked quarterbacks just three times in five games. 
Armchair quarterbacks figure that is what has been keeping Richardson from that big senior breakout. He’s been sacked 14 times, which can lead to happy feet when he senses pressure coming from all directions, but so far, he’s been relatively healthy throughout this frontal and blindside attacking. 
So if receivers can get open, Saturday could be Sam’s day. 
Cyclone sports columnist Randy Peterson has been reporting on ISU during the past five decades. Follow @RandyPete. 53 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://dmreg.co/1Lk8yKD TOP VIDEOS
